title: If the Trustee withdraws their report of "no asset" AFTER the discharge, are they still "serving" under code 521(a)(3)
question: The Trustee filed a motion to withdraw their report of no asset. Is it effective immediately, or does he need a Court order to withdraw? also, is he still "serving"; i.e. can he request additional documents from us? and finally, can we challenge his motion to withdraw?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Chapter 7 bankruptcy,Bankruptcy trustee,Debt,Debt relief,Debt discharge,Bankruptcy and debt,Professional ethics,Court orders
answers: As long as the case is not closed he can. And if you don't have a lawyer, you need one now.

The worst part is that if there was property that was concealed from the trustee, then he or she can move to have the discharge revoked under Section 727. Were you represented by an attorney? If not, I would suggest retaining one now.

Anything can be challenged. However, likely the Trustee found an asset that was not disclosed at the time of the initial review period. Because the case was still open the Trustee is well within his or her authority to withdraw their own report.

Jonathan Leventhal, esq.
Leventhal Law Group, P.C.
818-347-5800

NO EX-PARTE NOTICE VIA VOICE MAIL OR EMAIL: I do not accept e-mail notice for ex parte Applications via voicemail or by email. You must comply with California Law and give notice to a person in my office during regular business hours.

If the trustee took that step , that is unusual and likely not great news for the debtor No, the court doesn't have to sign off on that. He is not withdrawing from the case, just keeping the creditors meeting open so he can administer an asset of some sort.
